item.title: [SPR-465] <spring:message> tag does not work without DispatcherServlet
item.description:
The <spring:message> tag does not work when using Struts as the web tier instead of Spring. Basically, the MessageTag extends the RequestContextAwareTag, which delegates to RequestContextUtils. RequestContextUtils looks up items stored in the request by the DispatcherServlet. So, if you're coming from some other servlet (your own, Struts, etc) you are out of luck.

I think the best solution would probably be to move some methods in RequestContextUtils to WebApplicationContext (e.g. - getLocaleResolver, getLocale). This approach seems reasonable considering the WebApplicationContext interface already implements the ThemeSource interface.

I was going to try to submit a patch but it looks like the needed changes are a little more involved than I initially supposed, and it looks like there are several potential implementation strategies.
item.summary: <spring:message> tag does not work without DispatcherServlet

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
<spring:message> is not really meant to be used outside of DispatcherServlet requests. The Locale is user-specific, so can't be stored in the root WebApplicationContext; just the LocaleResolver could, but that might vary between different modules of your application too.

Currently, only a DispatcherServlet contains a LocaleResolver, which makes the message tag dependent on it. The main question is: Where to get the Locale to use from, without building a LocaleResolver into the root application context (where it doesn't really belong)? We could fall back to request.getLocale(), of course...

Juergen

Hmm well I don't really understand all the LocaleResolver stuff because I'm not familiar with Spring MVC, but it sounds like using a LocaleResolver isn't the way to go.

How this came up is that I wanted to use Spring's reloadable resource bundles in my app. I have those working, but of course now the JSTL and Struts' custom tags are useless. I think it's a perfectly reasonable strategy to fall back to request.getLocale(), because that's what other frameworks do anyway (OK I made that up... I know Struts at least works that way though). This change would allow Spring/Struts integrations to use reloadable resource bundles and Spring's <spring:message> tag (which I prefer to the JSTL and Struts versions) without requiring a wholesale adoption of Spring MVC.

I've generally reworked the RequestContext and all Spring JSP Tags to work outside a DispatcherServlet too now, falling back to the root WebApplicationContext as MessageSource. For the locale, a JSTL locale attribute is detected ("javax.servlet.jsp.jstl.fmt.locale"), else the accept-header locale is used (request.getLocale).

Juergen
I just had a chance to test this, and the <spring:message> tag is working great without Spring MVC. Thanks!
